Name: Fragaria virginiana (Fragaria platypetala)
Descript: Perennial herbs with scaly rootstock and runners which root at the nodes.  Leaves and flowers in basal tufts.  Three leaflets per leaf.  Flowers white to pinkish, petals round  to elliptical, 5 petals and sepals.

Name: Galium aparine
Descript: Annual.  Grows along ground and over other plants. 6-8 leaves in a whorl, mostly linear-oblanceolate, mostly 1.5-7 cm long, bristle-tipped, with coarse divergent or reflexed marginal setae.

Name: Galium bolanderi
Descript: Stems erect or diffusely spreading, tufted, from slender woody underground branches from a central root, 1-4 dm high,  slender, angled, glabrous except sometimes on the angles.  Leaves in 4's, oblong to lance-oblong, acute, glabrous or hispid-ciliate, 0.6-1.5 cm long.

Name: Galium sparsiflorum
Descript: Erect or spreading perennial from a woody root with subterranean rootstocklike branches, 2-5 dm long, leaves in 4's, glabrous to hispidulous, oval or ovate, 8-15 mm long.

Name: Galium trifindum
Descript: Slender stemmed perennial, ascending, branched and intertangled, 1.5-4 dm long.  Leaves elliptic-oblong to linear-spatulate, obtuse, not bristle-pointed, in 4's, 5's and 6's, thin, obscurely scabrous on margins and midribs, 0.5-2cm long.

Name: Galium triflorum
Descript: Perennial, with weak simple or remotely forking smooth or more or less scabrous herbaceous stems 2-8 dm long.  Leaves mostly in 6's, oblong-ovate to obovate, thin, cuspidate, 1.5-6 cm long, the surfaces mostly glabrous, margins and midribs beneath minutely scabrous.

Name: Garrya fremontii
Sp-Notes: not previously listed on master list
Descript: A shrub, not very common on Blodgett, which might be mistaken for a manzanita.  Opposite leaves.  Has been found in compartment 451.

Name: Gaultheria ovatifolia
Descript: An evergreen, matted, scarcely woody plant rarely more than a foot high.  Relatively common in wet areas.

Name: Gayophytum spp.
Descript: A common weed in disturbed areas.  Plants dichotomously branched, 1-6 dm high.  Leaves lance-linear, mostly 1-3 cm long, short-petioled.  Flowers white, often drying to pink or red, 4 petals, 0.5-7 mm long.

Name: Gnaphalium canescens (G. microcephalum)
Sp-Notes: Name change, Jepson '93.  No specimen with this species name  found in herbarium.  Some unidentifed Gnaphalium specimens do exist

Name: Goodyera oblongifolia
Descript: Small white to greenish flowers in mid-summer.  White mottled stripes on the leaves.  May be confused with white-veined wintergreen (Pyrola picta).

Name: Helenium Bigelovi
Sp-Notes: Specimen not identified to species level.

Name: Hypericum perforatum
Descript: A perennial weed, common on disturbed areas.  Opposite leaves, linear to elliptic-oblong, revolute, 1.5-2.5 cm long, subtending short leafy branchlets, opposite, stems oppositely branched.  Showy yellow flowers.  Somewhat  poisonous to livestock.

Name: Iris Hartwegii
Descript: Three erect "petals", three drooping "petals".  Light yellow flowers in spring.  Generally found in dry areas.

Name: Juncaceae
Sp-Notes: Many specimens not identified to the species level.

Name: Juncus bufonius (var. halophilus now J. ambiguus)
Sp-Notes: One variety now goes by a different species name.  Uncertain which variety we have here.  Jepson '93

Name: Achillea millefolium
Sp-Notes: Single species recognized in California by Jepson '93.
Descript: Perennial aromatic herb with alternate subentire to pinnately dissected (feathery) leaves. Heads several to many, rather small, in terminal corymbs, radiate (rarely discoid).  Ray flowers white, sometimes pink or yellow. Disk flowers white to yellow.

Name: Adenocaulon bicolor
Common: Trail Plant, Trail marker, path finder
Descript: A perennial herb with triangular-shaped leaves, 5-12 cm long and wide.  Leaves are green above, greyish-white below.  The common name comes from the factr that the whitish leaves show as trails after someone walks through an area where these plants grow.  Usually found in moist, undisturbed areas.

Name: Agoseris retrorsa
Descript: Annual or perennial herbs common in disturbed areas. Leaves in radical tufts or scattered on lower stem, pinnately lanceolate with the lobes pointing back to base of plant.  Flowers yellow to orange, 2-6 cm long, with heads 5-20 mm wide.

Name: Allium spp.
Sp-Notes: Listed as one of most common species of Blodgett but no specimen in herbarium
Descript: Wild onions.  Perianth-segments distinct or nearly so.

Name: Anemone quinquefolia some var now  A. oregana
Descript: Perennials, leaves mostly basal, stem leaves 2 or 3 together forming an involuchere subtending the flower.  Flowers showy.

Name: Apocynum spp.
Descript: A small perennial plant with opposite leaves.

Name: Aquilegia spp.
Descript: Perennials, stems usually several, erect, branched.  Leaves  mostly basal, 2-3 ternate, the stem leaves gradually reduced.  Flowers showy, 5-merous, each petal spurred.

Name: Arabis spp.
Descript: Bienial or perennial, stems leafy, often branched above.  Leaves dentate to entire, the basal petioled, the cauline usually sessile.  Infloresence racemose, bractless, elongating. 4 petals and sepals.

Name: Arctostaphylos patula
Descript: Most common manzanita on Blodgett.  An evergreen brush species which can quickly dominate harvested areas.  Sprouts if cut or burned.  Manzanitas can be a major competitor of commercial conifers causing slow seedling & sapling growth.  Seeds may remain viable in soil and duff for more than 100 years.  Unlike A. viscida, with which this species hybridizes, the buds are not sticky.

Name: Arctostaphylos viscida
Descript: Common on Blodgett.  Not generally a sprouting species. Evergreen.  Buds are usually sticky.  May hybridize with A patula.

Name: Asclepias spp.
Descript: A small perennial plant with opposite leaves, milky sap.

Name: Athyrium Filix-femina var. cyclosorum Rupr.
Sp-Notes: Name change, Jepson '93  Specimen not mounted.
Descript: Fronds 6-15 dm high.  2-3 times pinnate.  Unbranched stems form clumps.  Found in moist areas.

Name: Athysanus pusillus
Sp-Notes: Specimen in the genus folder needs to be mounted.

Name: Berberis spp.
Sp-Notes: Species may be B. aquilinium.  Specimen not mounted.
Descript: Common on dry hillsides in Section 29.

Name: Blechnum spicant
Descript: May appear to be two different types of ferns since it has both sterile and fertile fronds.  Found in wet areas.  Fronds are once pinnate.

Name: Botrychium multifidum
Descript: Found in moist, open habitats.  Plant fleshy, 1-4.5 dm high  1-3 fronds per plant, each frond 1-4 times pinnate.

Name: Brassica geniculata  now called Hirschfeldia incan
Brassica spp.
Sp-Notes: Species in folder identified as B. geniculata
Descript: Erect branched annual to perennial herbs, basal leaves pinnatifid, those of the stem dentate or subentire.  Flowers showy, yellow in elongated racemes.  4 petals and sepals.

Name: Calochortus spp.
Descript: Common on clearcuts.  White or light colored flowers in the spring.

Name: Calyptridium umbellatum
Descript: Annual to perennial, stems several, spreading to suberect,  5-25 cm long.  Leaves largely basal in a dense rosette, spatulate, 2-7 cm long.  Flowers in a small umbell or cyme, sepals pink or white.

Name: Campanula prenanthoides
Sp-Notes: No distinct species shown in the herbarium.  Only identified to the genus level

Name: Chrysolepsis chrysophylla (Castanopsis c.)
Sp-Notes: Name change, Jepson '93.  New code of CHSE?  Specimens not mounted.
Descript: A small tree or large shrub.  Both chinquapin species are vigorous sprouters and can be major competitors of conifers. Evergreen.  Leaves generally have pointed tips and are "folded" along their midribs.

Name: Chrysolepsis sempervirens  (Castanopsis s.)
Sp-Notes: Name change, Jepson '93.  New code of CHSE?  Specimens not mounted.
Descript: The shrub form of chinquapin.  Common on the southern third of Blodgett.  A vigorous sprouter.  Evergreen.  Leaves have rounded tips and are relatively flat.

Name: Ceanothus cordulatus
Descript: Three basal veins on undersurface of leaves, light colored spines formed on the twigs.  Nitrogen fixer.  Deciduous.  Seed remains viable in the duff and soil for more than 100 years.

Name: Ceanothus integerrimus
Descript: The most common shrub on the northern 2/3s of Blodgett.  No  spines.  Three basal veins on leaf undersurface.  Excellent forage for either deer or cattle. Nitrogen fixer. Deciduous. Seed remains viable in duff and soil for more than 100 years.

Name: Ceanothus prostratus
Descript: Never more than a few inches tall.  Nitrogen fixer.  Evergreen.  Not a serious competitor of conifers.

Name: Cerastium glomeratum (C. viscosum)
Sp-Notes: Jepson '93 says old name misapplied.  Specimen unmounted.

Name: Chamaebatia foliolosa
Descript: Vigorous sprouter, but does not grow quickly from seed.  Common on west and south facing slopes.  Often a serious competitor of trees because of its ability to use soil moisture.

Name: Chimaphila umbellata (formerly var. Occidentalis)
Sp-Notes: Not recognized as unique variation. by Jepson '93.  Family moved from Pyrolacaceae
Descript: A small evergreen shrub, 1-4 dm tall, with small white to pink flowers in summer.

Name: Chlorogalum pomeridianum
Sp-Notes: listed as common plant found at Blodgett but no specimen in herbarium
Descript: Basal leaves surround a dark brown bulb.  White flowers have green mid-veins on their petals.

Name: Chrysothamnus spp.
Sp-Notes: listed with common plants found at Blodgett but no specimen in herbarium
Descript: An aggressive weed, rabbitbrush is currently rare on Blodgett Forest and we would like to keep it that way.  There is generally a reward of a six pack of the beer or soda pop of your choice for finding rabbitbrush plants on Blodgett.   Please show the forest manager the location of any plants you find.

Name: Cirsium spp.
Sp-Notes: Specific specimen is of C. vulgare.
Descript: There are thistle species other than bull thistle.

Name: Cirsium vulgare
Descript: A common European biennial weed found on clearcuts and other exposed areas.   Leaves are covered with spines.  First year  plants form a basal rosette of leaves.  Red-purple flowers bloom in the summer on second year plants.

Name: Clarkia spp.
Descript: Many species are found on Blodgett.  Leaves simple, pinnately veined, linear to ovate, entire to denticulate,sessile or short-petioled.  Inflorescence a leafy spike or raceme.  Flowers perfect, 4 petals and 4 sepals, ovary inferior.

Name: Collomia heterophylla
Descript: Annual or rhizomatous perennial herbs, erect to prostrate.  Stems simple or branched.  Leaves alternate, linear to subovate, entire to pinnately dissected.  Flowers in cymes or capitately congested or solitary and auxillary.  Corolla narrow-funnelform to trumpet shaped, red, purplish, blue, white or salmon-yellow.

Name: Convolvulus arvensis
Descript: Twining or trailing herbs, usually perennial.  Leaves alternate, usually petioled, commonly cordate or sagittate.  Flowers showy, white to purplish or rose or yellowish.

Name: Conyza spp.
Descript: Annual weed up to 2 m high.  Found in disturbed areas.  Leaves up to 10 cm long and 10 mm wide, oblanceolate, entire to slightly serrated.  Flower heads 3-4 mm high, about 2-4  wide, ray flowers white, inconspicuous, disk flowers cream-colored.

Name: Corylus cornuta  Marsh var. californica
Sp-Notes: Not on the list, yet in the herbarium.  Added to list 7/95.

Name: Cuscuta spp.
Sp-Notes: Specimens shown parasitizing Ceanothus, Cornus & Arctostaphylos
Descript: Orange-colored parasitic plants, often growing on Ceanothus cordulatus or Ribes roezlii.

Name: Cytisus scoparius
Location: A large community is located three chains north of plot 165 in Section 29.
Descript: An aggressive European weed, broom is currently rare on Blodgett and we would like to keep it that way. There is generally a reward of a six pack of the beer or soda pop of your choice for finding broom plants on Blodgett.  Please  show the forest manager the location of any plants you find.

Name: Delphinium spp.
Descript: Erect branching perennials.  Leaves palmately lobed or divided.  Flowers in showy spikes or racemes, 4 petals, one sepal spurred.  Several species are poisonous.

Name: Dicentra formosa
Descript: Common in clearcuts.  White to rose-purple flowers in the spring and early summer.  Foliage is poisonous if eaten.

Name: Disporum hookeri
Sp-Notes: No longer a distinct variation, Jepson '93.
Descript: Creamy white flowers later forming red berries.  Leaves look similar to star flower or dogwood leaves but have parallel rather than net veination and are alternately arranged on the stem.

Name: Draperia systyla
Descript: Low diffuse perennial herb with slender stems from slender horizontal woody branches of the root-crown.  Leaves opposite, entire.  Flowers in naked terminal subsessile branched cymes.

Name: Cephalanthera austiniae (Ebuorophyton austinae)
Sp-Notes: Genus name change, Jepson '93.  New code CEAU?
Descript: A white to cream-colored plant with scale-like leaves.

Name: Elymus spp.  Many species now in genera Taeniather
Equisetum arvense
Descript: Found in moist habitats.  Ridged, hollow, round stems, leaves bristle-like in whorls around the stem.

Name: Erigeron inornatus
Sp-Notes: Species split into E. reductus A Gray var. angustatus and E. inornatus, Jepson '93.

Name: Eriogonum nudum
Descript: Annual or perennial herbs or shrubs with basal or cauline alternate to whorled entire leaves  without stipules.  Flowers very small, borne in clusters.  Fruit an achene, usually 3 sided.

Name: Erodium cicutarium
Descript: An annual herb, leaves usually first forming a close rosette  on the ground, 3-10 cm long, pinnate, opposite.  The fruit resembles a needle or birds bill, about 2-6 cm long and quite thin.

Name: Juncus spp.
Descript: There are many species and several genera of rushes on Blodgett Forest.  Unless the genus or species is known use the family code.

Name: Juncus tenuis
Sp-Notes: Some varieties of this species are now recognized as unique species, Jepson '93.

Name: Kelloggia galiodes
Descript: A small herb with pairs of lanceolate opposite leaves, 1-3 cm long, 3-8 mm wide.

Name: Leucothoe davisiae
Descript: An evergreen shrub 1.5-5 feet tall with shiny green alternate leaves and green stems.  Oblong leaves 1-3" long, small whitish flowers in racemes.  Foliage is toxic.  Found in wet areas, especially in the Gaddis Creek drainage.

Name: Lilium parvum
Sp-Notes: Specimen in herbarium with question mark next to species name.
Descript: Yellow-orange to red petals spotted with maroon.  Flowers erect or ascending.  Generally found in wet areas.  Flowers in early summer.  Usually multiple flowers per stalk.

Name: Lilium washingtonium
Sp-Notes: Listed as one of most common plants of Blodgett but no specimen in herbarium.
Descript: Large showy white flowers.  Usually found in dry areas.  Flowers in early summer.  Usually a single flower per stalk.

Name: Linnaea borealis spp. longiflora
Descript: A small trailing plant with opposite leaves and pairs of flowers growing from stalks rising from the main stem.

Name: Lithocarpus densiflorus
Descript: Can either grow as a tree or large shrub.  Leaves are usually serrated.  Sprouts when cut.  Can be a major  competitor of conifers.  Evergreen.

Name: Lonicera involucrata
Descript: A medium to large shrub with opposite leaves.  Found in moist areas.

Name: Lotus oblongifolius
Sp-Notes: Has a question mark next to it.  Perhaps it needs to be confirmed.  It was not previously in the list.

Name: Lotus spp.
Sp-Notes: There are many unmounted specimens of Lotus.
Descript: Annual or perennial herbs, leaves alternate, pinnately 1- to several folioate.  Flowers axillary, solitary to  umbellate, sessile or on short to long, mostly leafy-bracteate peduncles, corolla white or yellow, often with some red or purple.

Name: Lupinus spp.
Sp-Notes: Many extra specimens of this already mounted.  None identified to the species level.
Descript: Annual or perennial herbs or shrubs, palmately compound alternate leaves, showy flowers in terminal racemes.

Name: Madia elegans
Sp-Notes: Specimens not identified with this species name.  Several specimens offer two options:  exigua, minima

Name: Medicago spp.
Descript: Annual or perennial herbs, leaves pinnately 3-foliate, the leaflets mostly dentate.  Flowers in small heads, racemes or umbels.

Name: Melilotus albus
Descript: A common roadside weed, 1-2 m tall with small pinnately trifoliate leaves and tiny white flowers.

Name: Mimulus spp.
Descript: Annual or perennial herbs or low shrubs, often sticky.  Leaves opposite, entire to dentate or even laciniate, flowers axillary to foliage leaves or bracts, often in open racemes.  Bracteoles none.  Sepals 5, united into a tubular or campanulate calyx.  Corolla 2-lipped to subregular, purple, or red or almost violet to yellow or buff, witha  pair of bearded or naked ridges running down the lower side of the throat and forming a palate which may almost close the throat.

Name: Claytonia perfoliata (Montia perfoliata)
Descript: Flowers grow from the center of a 1-8 cm wide disc-shaped leaf. Leaves opposite.  Stems 1-3 dm tall.

Name: Myrica hartwegii
Descript: Considered but not included in the California Native Plant Society rare plants list.  Found near Mutton Creek, other stream banks.

Name: Navarretia spp.
Descript: Small annuals, mostly with rigid stems, erect and simple to  divaricately branched from base or along the stems.  Flowers sessile or nearly so in spiny densely bracted heads.

Name: Orthilia secunda (Pyrola secunda in Pyrolaceae)
Sp-Notes: Jepson '93 moved Pyrola to Ericaceae from Pyrolacaceae and changed name from Pyrola secunda to Orthilia s.

Name: Penstemon spp.
Descript: Perennial herbs or shrubs, leaves opposite, rarely whorled or the upper alternate, the lower usually petioled, the upper sessile.  Flowers usually showy, in racemose, cymose or thyrsoid panicles.  Calyx 5-parted. Corolla tubular, the throat often inflated, the limb weakly or strongly 2-lipped, the upper lip 2-lobed, the lower 3-cleft.

Name: Phacelia spp.
Sp-Notes: not previously noted in the master list
Descript: Annual or perennial herbs, usually more or less pubescent and often glandular.  Leaves mostly alternate, ranging from  entire or dentate to pinnate or bipinnate.  Flowers few to many, in dense to lax simple or branched cymes.  Small purple or blue to white or yellow flowers.

Name: Poaceae (Gramineae)
Sp-Notes: Jepson '93.  Family name change to Poaceae.  New code?
Location: There are many species and several genera of grasses on Blodgett Forest.  Unless the genus or species is known use the family code.

Name: Polygala cornuta
Descript: A small plant with alternate ovate to almost linear leaves 2-4cm long.  Plants usually have many slender stems which are 1-3 feet tall.

Name: Polygonum arenastrum (Polygonum aviculara)
Sp-Notes: Name change, Jepson '93.  Specimen not mounted.

Name: Polystichum munitum
Sp-Notes: No specimen in herbarium yet listed as one of common plants of Blodgett

Name: Polystichum scopulinum
Sp-Notes: Specimen not identified to species level.

Name: Populus fremontii
Descript: Not seen on Blodgett since the 1970's.

Name: Potentilla spp.
Descript: Perennial, sometimes annual, herbs.  Leaves pinnately or digitately compound.  Flowers perfect, solitary or cymose, 5 petals and sepals, stamens few to many.

Name: Prunella vulgaris spp. Lanceolata
Descript: Dense clusters of small purplish flowers.  Generally found in wet areas.

Name: Prunus emarginata
Descript: Glands on leaf margin near petiole.  Can be a major competitor of conifers.

Name: Prunus virginiana var. demissa
Sp-Notes: Listed as one of the most common species of Blodgett but not in Herbarium
Descript: Glands on the leaf petiole.  Can be a major competitor of conifers.

Name: Pteridium aquilinum var. pubescens
Descript: A major competitor of conifers in some areas.  Sprouts from rhizomes in the soil.  Best growth in open areas.  Fronds generally 2-3 times pinnate then pinnatifid.

Name: Pterospora andromedia
Descript: A purple brown to reddish  a-chlorophytic root-parasite.

Name: Pyrola picta
Sp-Notes: Jepson '93 moved Pyrola to Ericaceae from Pyrolacaceae.  New code?
Descript: Prominent white veins on leaves.  White to pink flowers in summer.  May be confused with rattlesnake orchid (Goodyera oblongifolia).

Name: Quercus kelloggii Newb.
Sp-Notes: Specimen in herbarium not previously listed on master list.

Name: Ranunculus spp.
Descript: Usually perennial herbs.  Leaves alternate, entire to compound, mostly basal.  Showy flowers, usually 5 shiny yellow petals.  Some species are poisonous.

Name: Rhamnus spp.
Descript: Low shrubs, 1-1.5 m high, spreading or rounded, mostly with reddish subglabrous twigs.  Leaves alternate, arcuate pinnately veined, 2-6 cm long.  Fruit a black, obovoid to  globose berry, mostly less than 1 cm in diameter.

Name: Rhododendron occidentale
Descript: Only found in moist areas.  Has clusters of large, fragrant, white flowers in the early summer.  Deciduous.

Name: Ribes roezlii
Sp-Notes: formerly in the Saxafragaceae family.  Changed with Jepson '93.
Descript: The alternate host of white pine blister rust.  Spines on stem and fruit.  Palmately lobed leaves.  Not generally eaten by cattle.

Name: Ribes spp.
Sp-Notes: formerly in the Saxafragaceae family.  Changed with Jepson '93.

Name: Rorippa curvisiliqua
Sp-Notes: Specimen not identified to species level.

Name: Rosa gymnocarpa
Sp-Notes: Listed as one of most common plants of Blodgett but no specimen identified as being this species.
Descript: 5 to 7 leaflets per leaf.  Leaves more or less glabrous on both surfaces, 1-4 cm long.  Purple flowers in spring and summer.  May be found in open areas or under forest canopy. Generally taller than R. pinetorum.

Name: Rosa pinetorum
Sp-Notes: Listed as one of most common plants of Blodgett but no specimen identified as being this species.
Descript: Usually 5 leaflets per leaf.  Leaves puberulent and glandular on lower surfaces, 1-3 cm long.  Purple flowers in spring and summer.  May be found in open areas or under forest canopy.  0.5-1 m tall.

Name: Rubus glaucifolius
Descript: Often found in relatively open, moist areas.  Not a major competitor of conifers.  Leaves whitish on undersurface.  Fine prickles on stem.  California native.

Name: Rubus laciniatus
Descript: Often found in relatively open, moist areas.  Not a major competitor of conifers.  Native of Europe.  Leaves deeply cleft.  Stout prickles.

Name: Rubus parviflorus
Descript: Found in moist areas.  Not a major competitor of conifers. California native.  Large soft palmately lobed simple leaves.  No prickles on stem.

Name: Rubus discolor (R. procerus)
Descript: Often found in relatively open, moist areas.  Not a major competitor of conifers.  Native of Europe.  Leaflets fairly  large and regular in shape.  Stout prickles on stem.

Name: Rubus vitifolius
Sp-Notes: Listed as one of most common plants of Blodgett but no specimen identified as this species.
Descript: Often found in relatively open, moist areas.  Not a major competitor of conifers.  Leaves shape is variable on single  plant, sometimes 2 or 3-lobed.  Prickles quite fine.

Name: Rumex spp.
Descript: Annual or mostly perennial herbs with simple or branched grooved stems.  Flowers numerous, mostly greenish, small, usually crowded and commonly whorled in panicled racemes.  Leaves often mostly basal, the cauline alternate, the petioles sheathing at base.

Name: Salicaceae
Descript: There are several species of willow found on Blodgett, generally in wet places.  Twigs are often green, buds are capped.  Leaves mostly narrow, pinately veined.

Name: Salix sessilifolia (S. exigua)
Sp-Notes: Possible name change due to splitting of species.  See Jepson '93 for clarification.

Name: Salix lucida ssp. lasiandra (S. lasiandra)
Sp-Notes: Possible  name change with splitting of species, Jepson '93.

Name: Sambucus caerulea
Sp-Notes: listed as common plant found at Blodgett but no specimen in herbarium
Descript: A large shrub (rarely a tree) with opposite, compound leaves.  Clusters of edible blue berries ripen in the fall.

Name: Senecio integerrimus
Sp-Notes: Specimens in the herbarium may be S. aronicoides instead of S. intergerrimus

Name: Sidalcea spp.
Sp-Notes: The single specimen is not mounted.

Name: Silene californica
Descript: A perennial forb with bright red flowers.

Name: Sisyrinchium elmeri
Descript: All six "petals" in the same plane.  Yellow flowers in summer.  Usually found in wet areas.

Name: Sisyrinchium idahoense
Descript: All six "petals" in the same plane.  Blue to purplish flowers in summer.  Usually found in wet meadows.

Name: Smilacina racemosa (formerly var. Amplexicaulis)
Descript: Common understory plant in relatively undisturbed areas. Stem erect, 3-9 dm high, leaves 7-20 cm long, 3-10 cm wide.

Name: Smilacina stellata
Descript: Understory plant in relatively undisturbed areas.  Stem erect, 3-6 dm high, leaves 5-15 cm long, 15-30 mm wide.

Name: Stachys rigida
Sp-Notes: No Stachys specimen identified as this particular species, yet listed as one of the most common plants of Blodgett
Descript: Rings of flowers just above each pair of leaves.

Name: Symphorocarpus mollis (S. acutus)
Common: Spreading Snowberry, Creeping Snowberry, Trip vine
Sp-Notes: S. acutus no longer considered separate from S. mollis, Jepson '93.
Descript: A low, vine-like plant common throughout the forest.  Leaves opposite and either roundish or gently lobed.

Name: Toxicodendron diversilobum
Sp-Notes: We need to get a specimen of this for people to refer to
Location: Common in North part of section 29
Descript: This poisonous plant is found only in Section 29 on Blodgett Forest.  It is particulary common North of Peavine Road.  Avoid any contact with it.  Oil from any part of the plant can cause severe skin irritation after several days.  Wash off as soon after possible with cold water and mild detergent.

Name: Trientalis latifolia
Descript: One of the most common plants on Blodgett.  Never a major tree competitor since the plants are always small.  Small white flowers in the spring and early summer.

Name: Trifolium spp.
Descript: Herbs with mostly palmately trifoliate leaves and adnate stipules.  White, yellow, pink to rose or purple flowers in heads.

Name: Triteleia hyacinthina (Brodiaea hyacinthina)
Sp-Notes: Not formerly on the list.  Specimen not mounted.

Name: Triteleia ixiodes (Brodiaea lutea)
Sp-Notes: Old specimen yet not previously in list.  Name added to this list 6/95.  Name change from listed name, Jepson '93.  Family also merged from Amaryllidaceae.
Descript: Perennial herbs similar to onions.  Perianth-segments united into definite basal tube.

Name: Vaccinium parvifolium
Descript: Generally in shady or moist areas, common near the Cookhouse.   Could be mistaken for deerbrush on a quick glance.  Deciduous.

Name: Verbascum thapsus
Descript: A biennial Eurasian weed common along roadsides or in clear- cuts.  In the first year plants form a basal rosette of leaves.  Second year plants have yellow flowers clustered along a tall stalk in the summer.

Name: Viola lobata
Descript: Small yellow flowers in spring or early summer.  Found both in open areas and under the forest canopy.  Leaves variable, either palmately 3-7 (9) cleft, or divided into lance-oblong lobes.  Several other species of violets are also found on Blodgett.

Name: Viola purpurea  (some subspecies = new species)
Sp-Notes: Several new species described from this species, Jepson '93

Name: Woodwardia fimbriata
Descript: A large fern found near water.  Fronds 10-25 dm long. Dicots flowering plants with leaf veins usually pinnate (feather-like) or palmate (like fingers extending from your palm)

Name: Cyperaceae
Descript: There are many species and several genera of sedge on Blodgett Forest.  Unless species or genus is known use the family code.

Name: Triteleia lilacina (Brodiaea hyacinthina)
Sp-Notes: Not formerly on the list.  Specimen not mounted.

Name: Torreya californica
Descript: Very spiny needles.  Otherwise it often looks like a large-needled white fir.
